description:
It's the dawn of the Golden Age of Aviation on planet Prester, and retro-futuristic sky vehicles known as vanships dominate the horizon. Claus Valca – a flyboy born with the right stuff – and his fiery navigator Lavie are fearless racers obsessed with becoming the first sky couriers to cross the Grand Stream in a vanship. But when the high-flying duo encounters a mysterious girl named Alvis, they are thrust into the middle of an endless battle between Anatoray and Disith – two countries systematically destroying each other according to the code of chivalric warfare. Lives will be lost and legacies determined as Claus and Lavie attempt to bring peace to their world by solving the riddle of its chaotic core.

(Source: Funimation)

tags.name: Aviation
tags.description: Regarding the flying or operation of aircraft.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Steampunk
tags.description: Prominently features technology and designs inspired by 19th-century industrial steam-powered machinery.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Lost Civilization
tags.description: Featuring a civilization with few ruins or records that exist in present day knowledge.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Cult
tags.description: Features a social group with unorthodox religious, spiritual, or philosophical beliefs and practices.

node.description:
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/ムラオミノル)

Originating from [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/).

__Doujin Circle:__ PASTA'S ESTAB.

[Website](https://www.pseweb.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/Murata_Range)

Renji "Range" Murata is a Japanese artist and designer, known for his unique style combining Art Deco and Japanese Anime elements. He is best known for his conceptual design work on [Last Exile](https://anilist.co/anime/97/Last-Exile/) and [Blue Submarine No. 6](https://anilist.co/anime/1051/Blue-Submarine-No-6/).

He began his career in the early 1990s doing design work for video games, including having done the illustrations and character design for the fighting game series made by Atlus, *Power Instinct (豪血寺一族, Goketsuji Ichizoku)*. Since 1996 he left the game company and went on to become a freelance illustrator.

He runs a doujin circle called *PASTA'S ESTAB.*, which publishes collections of illustrations from his various works as well as some original goods. He has published more than a dozen books of his work, some of the most notable being *Robot*, *Rule*, and *futurhythm*. He was also voted "Best Artist of the Year" in the 2006 Seiun Award.

Since 2013 Murata has served as a faculty member at the Kyoto Seika University's Faculty of Manga(Character Design Course). Artist [You Shiina](https://anilist.co/staff/105062/You-Shiina) is said to be among his students.

Range Murata selected an elite army of artists including [Yoshitoshi ABe](https://anilist.co/staff/96991/Yoshitoshi-ABe) and [Ugetsu Hakua](https://anilist.co/staff/102066/Ugetsu-Hakua) to contribute to *ROBOT* Volume 1 and ongoing.

**Notable works outside anime:**
~!
- Power Instinct (Arcade, 1993) (Back Designer) | (SNES, 1994) (Ending Design) *As Range
- Power Instinct 2 (Arcade, 1994) (Scroll Design) *As Range
- Tengai (SEGA Saturn, 1996) (Guest Illustrator)
- Groove on Fight: Gōketsuji Ichizoku 3 (Arcade, 1997) (Designer) *As Range
- Wachenröder (SEGA Saturn, 1998) (Main Character Design)
- Blue Submarine No. 6: Saigetsu Fumahito - Time and Tide (Dreamcast, 2000) (Character Design)
- Shin Gōketsuji Ichizoku Tōkon: Matrimelee (Arcade/Neo Geo, 2003) (Illustration)
- Spy Fiction (PlayStation 2, 2003) (Character Designer)
- Shin Gōketsuji Ichizoku: Bonnō no Kaihō (PlayStation 2, 2006) (Illustration)
- Gōketsuji Ichizoku: Senzo Kuyō (Arcade, 2009) (Illustration) !~

[Official Website ](http://kuroishihitomi.com/) | [Twitter ](https://twitter.com/kuroishihitomi) | [Spotify ](https://open.spotify.com/artist/1FXpihPpl4BxBlfGk3jfjx?autoplay=true)

Hitomi Kuroishi is a Japanese female singer-songwriter and composer, born in Kanazawa, Ishikawa Prefecture. She is credited simply as "Hitomi" for her vocals, not to be confused with J-pop singer "hitomi". Under Kim Studio (ケイ・アイ・エム; K, I, M). Used to be in 3-person unit Dolce Triade.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/前田真宏_(アニメ監督%29)

A prominent anime creator and one of the founders of studio [Gonzo](https://anilist.co/studio/3/).

While still in university, Maeda was part of a manga club together with [Yoshiyuki Sadamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/98158/), during which both of them got invited to participate on [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and [Daicon IV](https://anilist.co/anime/121664/). This brought Maeda enough recognition to get invited on the production of [Nausicaä](https://anilist.co/anime/572/), and the subseqeunt late '80s [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) films. He also worked on [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/)'s projects during this time.

In 1992, after having completely cut ties with Ghibli due to differences in working methods, Maeda founded Gonzo together with [Shinji Higuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/107646/), [Hiroshi Yamaguchi](https://anilist.co/staff/97308/) and [Shouji Murahama](https://anilist.co/staff/119708/), who were Gainax employees he had previously worked with on [The Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/) and [Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water](https://anilist.co/anime/1251/). At Gonzo he debuted as a director in 1998 with [Blue Submarine No.6](https://anilist.co/anime/1051/).

In 2004, Maeda directed [Gankutsuou](https://anilist.co/anime/239/), an adaptation of an 1844 novel, The Count of Monte Cristo, by [Alexandre Dumas](https://anilist.co/staff/102535/). Initially Maeda wanted to adapt an Alfred Bester novel, The Stars My Destination, but was rejected by the novel's copyright holders after proposing the numerous changes he wanted to make to the original narrative. He then searched for another work he could adapt into a science fiction setting and ended up going with The Count of Monte Cristo. The series was praised by Western critics and received multiple international accolades.

Called one of the most imaginative visualists in anime by Helen McCarthy, a British anime reference book author.

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

Known to have been a close friend of [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s before his passing.

**[Twitter](https://twitter.com/mill_sister)** | **[Website (blog)](https://blog.goo.ne.jp/gooussy)**

Kiyoko Sayama is a Japanese director, episode director, animation director and storyboard artist.

Married to [Tetsuya Kumagai](https://anilist.co/staff/101548/Tetsuya-Kumagai).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/秋山勝仁)

Acknowledged for his work in the [Inazuma Eleven](https://anilist.co/anime/5231/) franchise and numerous [AIC](https://anilist.co/studio/48/) shows in the '90s.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/秋山勝仁)

Acknowledged for his work in the [Inazuma Eleven](https://anilist.co/anime/5231/) franchise and numerous [AIC](https://anilist.co/studio/48/) shows in the '90s.

After having graduated from Tokyo Designer Gakuin, she joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), and started off as an animator. She is noted as the first female mecha director, and one of the few female directors in the '80s alongside [Makoto Moriwaki](https://anilist.co/staff/109581/) and [Hiroko Tokita](https://anilist.co/staff/101903/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).
_Note: Not to be confused with the [mangaka](https://anilist.co/staff/245226/Yuuichi-Tanaka)._

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ogura_koubou)

In 1977, Ogura joined *Kobayashi Production* and learned the ropes of art direction under [Shichirou Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/103964/Shichirou-Kobayashi). In 1983 he left and established Studio Fuga together with Kouji Oono and [Toshiharu Mizutani](https://anilist.co/staff/121908/Toshiharu-Mizutani). There he eventually left as well and formed his own 'Ogura Kobo' at Production I.G., where he trains newer art directors. He continues to be a major presence at Production I.G. as one of their most prominent art directors.

Ogura's style is, similar to Kobayashi's, rooted in imposing architecture, ambient colors, and Western perspectives versus traditional Japanese isometric perspectives. Ogura's backgrounds are usually urban in setting and has a less saturated color palette, and uses more cool than warm colors. Ogura's fantastical, European Kobayashi influence is easily seen in [Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/Ouritsu-Uchuugun-Honneamise-no-Tsubasa/), and his later work has remained distinctly metropolitan, something that can be seen even in the rural [FLCL](https://anilist.co/anime/227/FLCL/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/381332122)

She joined [Magic Bus](https://anilist.co/studio/207/) after having graduated from from Yoyogi Animation Academy. She holds a pencil and colored pencil in the same hand simultaneously which allows her to draw shading immediately after drawing the linework.

Her real name is Kumiko Sakai, and she is occasionally mistaken for a man due to her pseudonym, which she has been credited with since 2000. She is also friends with [Seiya Numata](https://anilist.co/staff/124320/), and they often participate in the same productions. They're both big idol fans and their friendship sparked due to a conversation about Morning Musume, a girl group.
__[Twitter](https://twitter.com/bbkoichi21)__

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/谷口守泰)

A veteran animator with a career spanning nearly 60 years.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ei_aoki)

Ei Aoki is a Japanese storyboard artist and director. He credits the anime Megazone 23 as his inspiration to have a career in animation. In 2013, he created the animation studio Troyca with Toshiyuki Nagano and Tomonobu Kato, which began animation production on its first work in the fall of 2014.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/ei_aoki)

Ei Aoki is a Japanese storyboard artist and director. He credits the anime Megazone 23 as his inspiration to have a career in animation. In 2013, he created the animation studio Troyca with Toshiyuki Nagano and Tomonobu Kato, which began animation production on its first work in the fall of 2014.
Dolce Triade is a Japanese music trio. The group was formed solely to write and perform the soundtrack of the anime series Last Exile.  Members:  Hitomi Kuroishi Maki Fujiwara Yuki Yamamoto

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/931752627359977472)

Currently mainly active at [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/).

Yoshigaki joined [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/) after graduating from Yoyogi Animation School. There he immediately got along with fellow animator [Hiroyuki Imaishi](https://anilist.co/staff/97349/), who joined the studio at the same time. Imaishi says that Yoshigaki is the "ideal animator."

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/森久司)

In the beginning of his career he was known for his sharp and clear [Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)-esque action scenes. After a while he abandoned his sharp style and shifted to a more realistic style that was more in line with [Mitsuo Iso](https://anilist.co/staff/100151/). At the time, the industry was filled to the brim with Iso followers, but according to [Takashi Hashimoto](https://anilist.co/staff/118452/); "The only people who wholly pursued Iso's style in animation were me, Mori, and [Shuuichi Kaneko](https://anilist.co/staff/143068/)."

(Source: Wikipedia)
Originating from Ad Cosmo.
